description: From Spanish garrote. Doublet of garrot.

entries.meaning: an iron collar formerly used in Spain to execute people by strangulation
examples: The Spanish had responded to the insurgency with characteristic brutality. They gave rebels the "usual four shots in the back" or the garrote - an iron collar tightened around the victim's neck with a screw until he was strangled to death.

entries.meaning: something, especially a cord or wire, used for strangulation
examples: The mob boss was known for having his enemies executed with a garrote of piano wire.

verbs.description: garrote (third-person singular simple present garrotes, present participle garroting, simple past and past participle garroted)
